Authors:
M Ramirez, R N Moncada, V Villegas-Escobar, Robert R.
Jackson, C A Ramirez
Title:
Phylogenetic and pathogenicity variability of Moko
disease-causing Ralstonia solanacearum strains in Colombia
Keywords:
Bacterial wilting, genetic variability, sequevars,
phylotype, Musa spp.
Abstract:
“Moko” disease, caused by the bacterium Ralstonia
solanacearum, is one of the most devastating diseases of Musa spp. in
Colombia, where banana and plantain are major crops. The disease
epidemiology is poorly understood and little is known about the
diversity of the bacterial populations associated to this disease. Here,
we assessed the diversity, phylogenetic relationship, and pathogenicity
of R. solanacearum strains associated to Moko disease in Colombia. For
this, we evaluated the genetic diversity of 65 isolates obtained from 4
banana/plantain-growing regions by using multiplex PCR and analyzing the
partial sequences of the mutS, rplB, and egl genes. These analyses
revealed that all the strains belonged to the R. solanacearum phylotype
II, sequevars 4 and 6. In addition, the phylogenetic analysis assorted
the strains into three subgroups, which matched the region of isolation:
1) Central region (i.e. Eastern plains and Andes, IIB/4), 2) Northwest
(i.e. Urabá and few strains from Magdalena, IIB/4), and 3) North coast
(Magdalena and few strains from Urabá, IIA/6). In addition, this
evolutionary pattern was associated with pathogenicity as 63 (out of 65)
of the isolates caused wilting of banana and plantain plants under
greenhouse conditions, but only 32, those isolated from the central
region (Eastern plains and the Andes), caused such symptoms in tomato
plants. In conclusion, our study shows that banana and plantain crops in
Colombia foster genetically diverse strains of R. solanacearum that
belong to, at least, three different genetic groups, which show
biogeographic and host range association.
